entry.title: These are the best dishes to try in Kuala Lumpur
entry.summary:
The ebi katsu sando at Reka Bar consists of succulent prawn katsu between a soft, vibrant ube milk loaf. Innovative chefs are mixing traditional ingredients with modern techniques in Malaysia's capital.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).¬†¬†
The dining scene in Kuala Lumpur has long reflected Malaysia‚Äôs rich cultural tapestry, with traditional Malay, Chinese and Indian cuisines as staples. And now, the city is embracing culinary innovation, too. From elevated street food to avant-garde fine dining, chefs are pushing boundaries with fusion dishes and unique ingredients. Here are the best places to experience the Malaysian capital‚Äôs ever-evolving food landscape.
This dish epitomises chef Darren Teoh‚Äôs commitment to celebrating local, indigen‚Ä¶

entry.title: Running Into Open Secrets: How to Investigate Using the Strava Fitness App
entry.summary: Journalists around the world have mined the Strava fitness app to¬†pinpoint secret military bases and track the movements of world leaders.

entry.title: Lentils and peas are overlooked protein powerhouses
entry.summary:
Beans hog the nutritional spotlight in the kitchen and on TikTok, but their fellow legumes lentils and peas pack high nutritional punches, too. These foods are so full of protein, fiber, and antioxidants that the American diet should be brimming with them, according to a recent report by the U.S. government‚Äôs 2025 Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee.
Various legumes are staples in Indian, Middle Eastern, and other cuisines but rare in classic American fare. ‚ÄúIt is embarrassing how few legumes people eat in the U.S.,‚Äù says Christopher Gardner, a nutrition scientist at Stanford University who helped author the new report. Even when people do eat them, he says, they lean towards the category‚Äôs most prominent member, beans.¬†
(Black beans, pinto, and cannellini are also nutritionall‚Ä¶

entry.title: ‚ÄòSharktopus‚Äô isn't alone‚Äîthese animals hitchhike on other animals.
entry.summary: A classic example of phoresy, the remora uses a modified fin that latches onto larger animals like a suction cup. Here three remoras (Remora brachyptera) ride a Chilean devil ray (Mobula tarapacana) off the coast of Santa Maria Island, Azores.  Cockroaches that catch a ride on ants. Grasshoppers that climb aboard sheep. Hitchhiking animals are more common than you think. Spend enough time in nature, and you will see some weird stuff‚Äîfrom orcas swimming around wearing salmon like hats to wombats pooping cubes. But when Rochelle Constantine saw a nine-foot-long mako shark jet past her research vessel in the Hauraki Gulf off New Zealand with a huge, orange octopus globbed onto its head, she knew she was witnessing something new.¬† ‚ÄúIt was jus‚Ä¶

entry.title: 10 eclectic, must-see museums in San Diego
entry.summary:
A visitor passes through the "Light Floor" art installation at the WNDR Museum in San Diego. To get a feel for the soul of San Diego, stop by these innovative museums found in Balboa Park and along the scenic coastline.
San Diego‚Äôs epicenter for arts and culture is Balboa Park. This 1,200-acre urban oasis is home to 18 museums (and dozens of gardens, attractions, and fun venues). Visit the traditional institutions here‚Äîor swing over to the¬†recently added¬†Comic-Con Museum.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†
In case you didn‚Äôt know, Balboa Park shares a zip code with downtown San Diego, and the city‚Äôs urban core has its own set of eclectic offerings, like the nautical¬†USS Midway Museum¬†and¬†the Maritime Museum. With so many museums in the city, museophiles can pare down their options with this helpful list o‚Ä¶

entry.title: We planned the perfect day in San Diego for 3 types of travelers
entry.summary:
Travelers visiting San Diego can plan the perfect day trip to explore the city with three itineraries designed for families, adventurers, and culture enthusiasts. San Diego is known as the heart of SoCal surf culture, but there's more to this city than just beaches and sunny weather. Here‚Äôs how to explore the city‚Äôs intriguing history, impressive museums and vibrant neighborhoods.
While Spanish explorer Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo failed to find an all-water route‚Äîthe mythical ‚ÄúStrait of Anian‚Äù‚Äîacross North America in 1542, he did discover San Diego Bay, which he remarked was ‚Äúa very good port.‚Äù The Indigenous Kumeyaay people had already lived there for thousands of years. Cabrillo still claimed the land for Spain, beginning a tumultuous period where San Diego would be under Spanish, t‚Ä¶

entry.title: The brain has a secret survival trick to endure a marathon
entry.summary:
A marathon taxes more than just muscles‚Äîit pushes the brain to its metabolic limits. New research shows that during extreme endurance events, the brain may burn its own fat for fuel, revealing just how adaptable‚Äîand surprising‚Äîthe mind can be. A study of long-distance runners shows the brain‚Äôs remarkable ability to adapt‚Äîby burning its own fat.
Carlos Matute wasn‚Äôt looking for a scientific breakthrough when he laced up his shoes for a long run. But as the miles ticked by, the¬†neuroscientist¬†from the University of the Basque Country found himself chasing a persistent question: ‚ÄúHow do we make it to the finish line, being conscious, after having our energy stores depleted?‚Äù¬†
That curiosity led to a surprising possible answer. In¬†a recent study¬†in¬†Nature Metabolism, Matute found ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Here are 9 top-notch sun hats for travelers
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*¬†
Every traveler knows sunscreen is essential for any trip. But experts also recommend supplementing lotions and creams with a good sun hat.¬†
The Skin Cancer Foundation says the overwhelming majority of skin cancers are caused by cells that first appear on the head and neck and recommends hats for extra protection. The best sun hats have wide brims, flaps to protect the ears and neck (especially for outdoor activities), tight weaving to block rays, a‚Ä¶

entry.title: Avoid crowds at the 10 least-visited U.S. national parks
entry.summary:
A camper gazes at the central Brooks Mountain Range, which includes East and West Maiden Peaks, Camel Peak, and Arrigetch Peaks‚Äîall found within the Alaska's Gates of the Arctic National Park and Preserve. Get off the beaten path at these under-the-radar wilderness areas.
Since its founding on August 25, 1916, the U.S. National Park Service has assembled 419 protected units, of which 62 hold the ‚Äúnational park‚Äù designation. To visit all 63 of these treasures one would need to travel to 29 states and two U.S. territories.
But with so many national parks to visit, there are trails, craters, and lakeshores that can be explored responsibly and without crowds. How remote and uncrowded are these parks? Katmai National Park‚Äôs Aniakchak caldera is so remote that many park rangers have‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to eat your way through San Diego like a local
entry.summary:
Mexican food and seafood are the obvious choices when visiting¬†San Diego. The culinary scene capitalizes on year-round perfect weather with rooftop terraces and oceanfront dining views. But the diversity of food options doesn‚Äôt stop at tacos.
¬†One neighborhood honors its historical heritage with authentic Italian restaurants, while another dedicates itself to representing the many cultures and flavors of Asian cuisine. Local craft beer is omnipresent, too. At local farmers‚Äô markets and restaurants, seasonal ingredients are showcased and usually plucked straight from one of the county‚Äôs 5,000 farms during peak ripeness.
Travelers looking to whet their palate with the best food in Southern California should fill their itinerary with these essential dishes and culinary experiences f‚Ä¶

entry.title: How a new pope is elected
entry.summary:
With the death of Pope Francis at the age of 88, the world will now turn to a pressing question: Who will be the next pope‚Äîand how will he be elected?
After Pope Benedict XVI‚Äôs resignation in 2013, it took two long weeks for the Catholic faithful to find out who would be their next representative of God on Earth.
Crowds in Saint Peter's Square at the Vatican let out a cheer as the white smoke from burned ballots signified a successful vote among the members of the College of Cardinals.¬†It was the final act that sealed the intricate papal selection process that allegedly dates back to the time of Jesus Christ.
Here‚Äôs a closer look at the real story behind one of the Vatican‚Äôs most mysterious and time-honored processes.
The pope was originally the bishop of Rome, a ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Pope Francis dies at 88
entry.summary:
Pope Francis passed away at the Vatican on April 21, after leading the Catholic faithful since March 2013. His election as pope was characterized by firsts: He was the first man from outside of Europe to become pope in more than 1,200 years, the first supreme pontiff from South America, and the first member of the Jesuits to preside as bishop of Rome.
As head of the Holy See, Francis broke much new ground, and his leadership represented a significant shift in the office itself, focusing on bridging the widening gap between the elite administration of the Catholic Church and its flock. He also pioneered new approaches to long-held Catholic traditions and practices.
(Take a close look at Pope Francis's first visit to the United States.)
Francis‚Äôs upbringing, training, an‚Ä¶

entry.title: An intimate look at Pope Francis's life at the Vatican
entry.summary:
Each morning Pope Francis awoke before dawn in his modest accommodation at Casa Santa Marta, the Vatican guest¬≠house. As day broke, Pope Francis prayed and meditated before delivering a homily at morning Mass.
By midday the pope had undertaken any number of duties, preferring to manage his schedule personally. Phone calls to colleagues and friends, meetings, and other appointments preceded lunch, after which he took a siesta.
His afternoons were often spent visiting prisons and juvenile detention centers, consulting with ambassa¬≠dors to the papacy, or making appointments. Once a week he received a soccer update from a member of the Swiss Guard, a necessity since the pope stopped watching television in 1990. Though Pope Francis may have given up television, he was an active lover of the arts. He enjoyed opera, classical music, and baroque artwork, and he identified Federico Fellini's La Strada¬†as his favorite film.
A few times a month, the pope led Papal Mass and hosted regular audiences in St. Peter‚Äôs Square or the Basilica (and sometimes both on busy days), which allowed tens of thousands of people to be in the pope‚Äôs presence. Often these individuals were from all over the world and wept and cheered when they caught a glimpse of the head of the Roman Catholic Church.
His evening meal was again taken among his fellow residents at the Casa Santa Marta. True to form, he never dined alone. Once back in his austere domicile, Pope Francis ended his day as it began‚Äîquietly. Each night, the pontiff read before drifting off to sleep.

entry.title: See how Pope Francis ushered in a new era for the Catholic Church
entry.summary:
Pope Francis always had an eye on the future. From the outset he recognized the need for a shift within the Catholic Church, which had lost the trust of many in recent years. His calls for change could be inspiring to many yet divisive to others as he ushered in transformational ideologies and a less formal period for the papacy.
As formality was thrust aside, older Catholic traditions were also reevaluated. In 2013, Francis named numerous women to roles high within the Vatican administration. When asked about the sexual preferences of priests, the pope replied, ‚ÄúIf someone is gay and he searches for the Lord and has good will, who am I to judge?‚Äù Pope Francis gave traditionalists within the Catholic Church pause, but subsequent statements in support of same-sex civil unions and about the ‚Äúunjust‚Äù criminalization of homosexuality attested to Francis‚Äôs vision for the future of the church.¬†
Francis also challenged the status quo by encouraging that the clergy make a place within the church for divorced and remarried Catholics. He urged them to ‚Äúoffer understanding, comfort and acceptance‚Äù to single mothers, ‚Äúrather than imposing straightaway a set of rules that only lead people to feel judged and abandoned.‚Äù¬†
In accordance with Pope Francis‚Äôs hope for global harmony and cooperation, he issued a call to action for all Catholics to protect the planet‚Äî‚ÄúGod‚Äôs creation‚Äù‚Äîin the face of environmental crises. And despite referring to himself as a ‚Äúdinosaur‚Äù when it came to computers, Pope Francis broke ground for the papacy by taking part in numerous online events, launching the Vatican into the digital age and connecting with millions of his flock.

entry.title: Try this Norwegian Arctic lodge for an intro to pack-rafting
entry.summary:
Raft and hike through Norway's Alta Canyon beneath the midnight sun. On a trip to Norway's Alta, get an off-the-radar taste of the wild with river-rafting and hiking beneath the midnight sun.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
At 70 degrees north, where Norway‚Äôs coast frays into fjords, islands and skerries, Alta is a true blast of the Arctic. A two-hour flight from Oslo, one of the world‚Äôs most northerly towns takes ‚Äòwild‚Äô to a new level. Here, the Northern Lights rave above snowy fells all winter long, while the midnight sun burns in summer. Porpoises, dolphins and whales splash in frigid waters and the indigenous S√°mi people herd reindeer on the stark tundra. entry.title: Data Don‚Äôts: Expert Tips to Avoid Misleading Audiences With Numbers
entry.summary: At a NICAR 2025 panel, data journalism experts discussed nuanced number errors that watchdog reporters often make that can confuse readers and disrupt story angles.

Á••ÊòäÔºåËøô‰∏™‰∏ñÁïåÁúüÂ•ΩÁé©„ÄÇ Êü•ÁúãÁü•‰πéÂéüÊñá
‰Ω†ÊòØ‰∏™‰∫åÂçäÂêäÂ≠ê‰∏ö‰ΩôËÄÉÂè§Â≠¶ÂÆ∂Ôºå ÂèëÁé∞‰∏Ä‰∏™Â•áÊÄ™ÁöÑÂ§¥È™®„ÄÇ Ê≠§Êó∂Â§ßË±°Áõ∏ÂÖ≥ËµÑÊñôÂÆåÂÖ®Ê∂àÂ§±Ôºå‰Ω†ÈúÄË¶ÅÊé®ÊµãËøôÁé©ÊÑèÊòØÂï•ÔºåÂï•‰π†ÊÄß„ÄÇ Ëøô‰∏™Â§¥È™®‰æßÈù¢ÈïøËøôÊ†∑Ôºå

Â§¥È™®‰∏§‰æßÊúâ‰ø©‰∏ä‰∏ãÊéíÂàóÈ¢ûÈ¢•Â≠îÁöÑÔºå ÊòØÂèåÂ≠î‰∫öÁ∫≤ÔºåËú•Ëú¥ÔºåÈ∏üÔºåÊÅêÈæôÁ≠âÂ∞±ÊòØÂ±û‰∫éËøô‰∏ÄÁ±ªÁöÑ„ÄÇ ÂêåÊ†∑ÔºåÂ§öÊï∞ÁâôÈΩøÈÉΩÈïøÂ∑Æ‰∏çÂ§öÔºåÁâôÈΩøÊ≤°ÊúâÂÖ∑‰ΩìÂäüËÉΩÂàÜÂåñÔºå‰πüÊòØÈáçË¶ÅÁâπÂæÅ‰πã‰∏Ä„ÄÇ
Êúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∏ã‰ΩçÈ¢ûÂ≠îÁöÑÔºåËøôÊòØÂêàÂºìÁ∫≤Âä®Áâ©ÁöÑÊ†áÂøóÊÄßÁâπÂæÅÔºåÂ∞±ÊòØÂì∫‰π≥Âä®Áâ©„ÄÇ Âì∫‰π≥Âä®Áâ©ÁöÑÈ¢ûÈ¢•Â≠îÂú®ÊºîÂåñ‰∏≠ÈÄêÊ∏êÈó≠ÂêàÔºåÂΩ¢Êàê‰Ωç‰∫éÁúºÁú∂ÂêéÊñπÁöÑÈ¢ûÁ™ùÔºåÁî®‰∫éÈ¢ûËÇåÈôÑÁùÄ„ÄÇ ÊâÄ‰ª•Âπ∂‰∏çÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÆû‰ΩìÁöÑÁ™üÁ™ø„ÄÇ ÊàñËÄÖÁÆÄÂçïÁÇπÔºåÊë∏‰∏ÄÊë∏ÁúºÂêéÊúâÊ≤°ÊúâÂ§™Èò≥Á©¥ÔºåÊúâÁöÑÂ∞±ÊòØÂì∫‰π≥Âä®Áâ©„ÄÇ Âè¶Â§ñÔºåÂì∫‰π≥Âä®Áâ©ÁöÑÁâôÈΩøÂ§öÊï∞ÊúâÂÖ∑‰ΩìÁöÑÂàÜÂåñÔºå‰πüÊòØÈáçË¶ÅÁâπÂæÅ‰πã‰∏Ä„ÄÇ ÂæàÊòéÊòæÔºåÂ§ßË±°ÁöÑÂ§¥È™®ÂÖ∑ÊúâÂÖ∏ÂûãÁöÑÂêàÂºìÁ∫≤Âä®Áâ©ÁâπÂæÅÔºåËÄå‰∏îÁâôÈΩøÊúâÂæàÊòéÊòæÁöÑÂàÜÂåñÔºåÊòØÂì∫‰π≥Âä®Áâ©Ê≤°Èîô„ÄÇ ÁÑ∂ÂêéÁúãÊûïÈ™®Â§ßÂ≠îÁöÑ‰ΩçÁΩÆÔºå ÊûïÈ™®Â§ßÂ≠îËøûÁùÄËÑäÊ§éÔºå Ê®™ÁùÄÁöÑËØ¥ÊòéËÑäÊ§éÊ∞¥Âπ≥ÔºåÁ´ñÁùÄÁöÑËØ¥Êòé‰∏ªË¶ÅÊòØÁõ¥Á´ãÊ¥ªÂä®ÔºåÁ´ñÁùÄÈù†ÂêéÁöÑÂ∞±ÊòØÂçäÁõ¥Á´ã‰∏∫‰∏ª„ÄÇ
ÂóØÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Âà§Êñ≠ÔºåËøôÊòØ‰∏ÄÁßçÈù†ÂõõË∂≥Ë°åËµ∞ÁöÑÂÖΩÁ±ª„ÄÇ ÁÑ∂ÂêéÁúãÁâôÈΩø„ÄÇ È£üËÇâÂä®Áâ©Êã•ÊúâÊòéÊòæÂ∞ñÈîêÁöÑÁä¨ÈΩøÔºåÁî®‰∫éÊçïÁåé„ÄÇËÄå‰∏îËáºÈΩøÊã•ÊúâÂæàÊòéÊòæÁöÑÂàÉÁä∂ËæπÁºòË£ÇÈΩøÁâπÂåñ„ÄÇ ËÄåÈ£üËçâÂä®Áâ©ÂàôÊã•ÊúâÈì≤Áä∂ÁöÑÈó®ÈΩøÔºåÁî®‰∫éÂâ™ÂàáÊ§çÁâ©„ÄÇËáºÈΩøÊõ¥Âπ≥ÈòîÔºåÊã•ÊúâÂ§çÊùÇÁöÑË§∂Áö±ÔºåÁî®‰ª•Á†îÁ£®Ê§çÁâ©„ÄÇ ËÄåÊùÇÈ£üÂä®Áâ©ÂàôÊòØ‰ªã‰∫é‰∏§ËÄÖ‰πãÈó¥„ÄÇ
ÂΩìÁÑ∂‰∫ÜÔºåËøòÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∫õÁâπ‰æãÔºåÊØîÂ¶ÇÊ≤≥È©¨ÔºåÈõÑÈ©¨ÔºåÁçêÁ≠âÈ£üËçâÂä®Áâ©‰πü‰ºöÈïøÂá∫Â∞ñÈîêÁöÑÁä¨ÈΩø„ÄÇ ÁâõÔºåÈπøÁ≠âÂèçÂàçÊ¨°ÁõÆÂä®Áâ©‰∏äÈ¢åÊ≤°ÊúâÈó®ÈΩøÔºåÂè™Êúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™ËßíË¥®ÂåñÁ°¨ËÖ≠Âû´„ÄÇ ËÄåÂ§ßË±°Ëøô‰∏™ÁâôÈΩøÂ∞±ÊúâÁÇπÈ¢†Ë¶Ü‰º†Áªü„ÄÇ È¶ñÂÖàÂêéÊéíËáºÈΩøÂÆΩÂ§ßÊúâ‰ºóÂ§öÂáπÊßΩÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Âà§ÂÆöËøôÊòØÈ£üËçâÂä®Áâ©„ÄÇ ‰ΩÜÊòØÔºå‰∏äÈó®ÈΩøË¢´ÁâπÂåñÊàê‰∫ÜÈïøÊù°Áä∂Â∑®ÁâôÔºå‰∏ãÈ¢åÈ™®ÂâçÈÉ®Êúù‰∏ãÂèçÂº†‰∏îÊ≤°Êúâ‰∏ãÈó®ÈΩøÔºå Â∞±ÈùûÂ∏∏Â•áÊÄ™„ÄÇ

entry.title: Best of Bohemia‚Äîdiscover 5 unmissable day trips from Prague
entry.summary:
Wrapped around Prague like an elegant scarf, Central Bohemia is a region rich in ancient history and natural beauty. Once at the heart of the Holy Roman Empire and the Habsburg realm, its storied past is evidenced at every turn by a parade of picture-perfect castles and cathedrals. Perhaps more surprising ‚Äî considering the region‚Äôs proximity to the Czech capital ‚Äî is the abundance of unspoilt nature, from forest-fringed rivers and natural springs, to yawning limestone caves and grand canyons. Here are five excellent reasons to add Central Bohemia to your next Czech adventure.
Macabre Sedlec Ossuary is probably Central Bohemia‚Äôs most photographed sight (though this has been restricted in recent years). From the outside, it looks like an unremarkable Catholic chapel, but step across t‚Ä¶

entry.title: Sudan war: Hundreds of thousands flee renewed violence in North Darfur
entry.summary: A mass wave of displacement in Sudan‚Äôs North Darfur state is pushing hundreds of thousands into precarious conditions far from lifesaving aid, as overstretched operations struggle to keep pace with the growing emergency.

entry.title: How to spend the perfect day in Dresden, Germany
entry.summary:
Before its destruction in the Second World War, Dresden was so famed for its beautiful baroque architecture that it was known as 'Florence on the Elbe'. Saxon puppetry, galleries and gardens: here's how to make the most of a short break in this German city.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
Dresden's mural-adorned courtyards, modern artworks and yellow trams combine to make it an enigmatic city break destination. The Saxon capital offers laidback restaurants, riverside cafes and buzzing nightlife districts, all set in the shadows of its stately baroque buildings.
Beat the crowds and tick off one of Dresden‚Äôs biggest draws early, admiring the colonnaded courtyards, galleries and gardens of the Zwinger Palace, a masterpiece of baroque arch‚Ä¶

entry.title: 6 hikes to try in the Rocky Mountains
entry.summary:
The 50 parking spots in the Emerald Lake lot tend to fill before 9am, so arrive early or park on the nearby Emerald Lake Road and walk to the lake. Explore trails in British Columbia that criss-cross Canada‚Äôs most spectacular mountain range ‚Äî whatever your level of experience and fitness.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Imagine a quintessentially Canadian landscape and you‚Äôre probably picturing the Rockies. These jagged peaks stretch 3,000 miles across the continent of North America, but some of the most soul-stirring sections straddle the border of British Columbia and Alberta. Whether you plan on a peaceful meander around a glacial lake or an expedition across dramatic mountain ridges, there‚Äôs a trail for every explorer. Nature-lovers will‚Ä¶

entry.title: Is this the most thrilling way to experience a Canadian river?
entry.summary:
To see the salmon in abundance, it‚Äôs far better to don a wetsuit and float down the shallow Campbell River from late July to September, when the salmon run is taking place. Home to one of the world's greatest salmon migrations, Campbell River lives up to its title as the 'Salmon Capital of the World', offering travellers the rare chance to snorkel among thousands of chinook, chum and coho.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Bald eagles circle overhead, black bears patrol the forested riverbank and harbour seals frolic in pools near the estuary mouth. Imagine you‚Äôre immersed in a fast-flowing river, face down with a mask and snorkel, observing one of nature‚Äôs greatest spectacles: a chaotic maelstrom of fish racing towards you, all possessed wit‚Ä¶

entry.title: Haiti‚Äôs independence debt to France focus of debate at UN
entry.summary: Two centuries to the day after France imposed a crippling debt on Haiti in exchange for its independence, a UN forum heard calls for the restitution of what has long been described as a ‚Äúransom‚Äù extorted under the threat of force from the Caribbean nation that still bears the scars of colonialism and slavery.

entry.title: Is there really alien life on this exoplanet? We asked 10 experts.
entry.summary:
An illustration shows what exoplanet K2-18b might look like based on data from NASA's James Webb Space Telescope. K2-18b is 8.6 times as massive as Earth, orbits the cool dwarf star K2-18 in the habitable zone and lies 120 light-years from Earth. A new study suggests it may have a molecule called dimethyl sulfide (DMS) in its atmosphere A team of astronomers claims to have sniffed out a ‚Äúbiosignature‚Äù in the atmosphere of a distant planet called K2-18b. But not everyone agrees that it signals life.
In 2020, scientists claimed to have found a sign of life on Venus: hints of a stinky gas called phosphine that‚Äôs made by microbes on Earth. The claim was swiftly challenged and, years later, is still mired in controversy. Now, another stinky gas has sparked its own alien life debate‚Äîthis‚Ä¶

entry.title: Rare, 1,600-year-old child remains found at a Maya altar
entry.summary:
Archaeologists excavating the ruins of the Maya city of Tikal have unearthed a 1,600-year-old altar likely used for human sacrifices, surrounded by the bones of children.
The grim discovery adds weight to the idea that Tikal was ruled at this time by overlords from the non-Maya city of Teotihuacan, more than 600 miles west in what‚Äôs now Mexico; and some of the sacrifices may have been efforts to ensure Teotihuacan‚Äôs power over the local people.
‚ÄúThe local dynasty, which was Maya, was allowed to continue, but under the heel of a foreign group,‚Äù says Brown University archaeologist Stephen Houston. In a new study in the journal Antiquity, Houston and his colleagues describe the altar and human remains unearthed from the ruins in what‚Äôs now Guatemala. The researchers think the altar ‚Ä¶

entry.title: What archaeology can‚Äîand can‚Äôt‚Äîtell us about Jesus‚Äô crucifixion
entry.summary:
Visitors flock to the renovated Edicule in the Church of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem's old city. From the location of the ‚Äúplace of skulls‚Äù to ancient Jewish burial rites, here‚Äôs what archaeologists do‚Äîand don‚Äôt‚Äîknow about the truth behind the Easter story.
The death and resurrection of Jesus is the most famous underdog story in history. A low-status artisan from Galilee challenged the authorities of his time and ended up dying a brutal and horrifying death. But only a few days later, the Bible says, he was vindicated and resurrected from the dead. The story inspires billions of Christians around the world, but how much hard evidence is there for the historical events that started a global religion?
From a historical perspective, the Easter story is tremendously well attes‚Ä¶

entry.title: A first-timer‚Äôs guide to Kaunas, Lithuania‚Äôs eternal city
entry.summary:
Kaunas has had numerous rulers over time, from the Teutonic Knights to the Russian Empire. Nonetheless, throughout the years, Lithuania‚Äôs second city (the fourth-largest in the Baltic states) has maintained its identity as a centre of culture and academia. Situated 62 miles west of Vilnius, Kaunas‚Äô architecture hints at the city‚Äôs great historical depth ‚Äî from the gothic spires of its medieval Senamiestis (Old Town) to its angular art deco apartment buildings and ultra-modern additions such as the new Science Island. Here‚Äôs how to experience it all in a weekend.
Get ahead of the summer crowds by visiting Kaunas in spring, when the Sakura Park cherry blossoms on Nemunas Island are in bloom. Cultural season kicks off in April with the Kaunas Jazz Festival. In late May, the city celebr‚Ä¶

entry.title: Myanmar: Thousands remain in crisis weeks after deadly earthquakes
entry.summary: Thousands of families in Myanmar remain without shelter, water, or medical care three weeks after deadly earthquakes struck the country, as frequent aftershocks compound the suffering of communities already battered by conflict and poverty.

entry.title: Why Greece‚Äôs Zagori is a hiker‚Äôs dream
entry.summary:
The Vikos Gorge trail in northwest Greece is 20 miles long, with the Voidomatis River forming a lake between the villages of Monodendri and Vikos. The footpaths that link the isolated mountain settlements of Zagori offer some of the most spectacular hiking in the whole of Greece.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Greeks don‚Äôt hike. You‚Äôll hear this everywhere you go in Greece ‚Äî usually from the locals themselves. They can‚Äôt see the point, apparently; uses up too much beach time.
If that‚Äôs the case then no one told Anna Diamantopoulou and her jovial group of trekking pole-wielding beginners. I encounter them on the steep stone path that snakes down into Vikos Gorge from the village of Monodendri. They‚Äôre audible long before they‚Äôre visible,‚Ä¶

entry.title: 7 compact and powerful travel routers
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*
Staying connected while traveling is important whether you need to work, want to stream your favorite shows, or just stay in touch with loved ones. However, public Wi-Fi can be unreliable and insecure, and international roaming fees can add up quickly. A travel router can solve these issues by offering secure, fast, and reliable internet access wherever you go.¬†¬†
‚ÄúUltimately, the big benefit to travel routers is simplifying your connections,‚Äù says S‚Ä¶

entry.title: How junk food outsmarts our brains‚Äîby hiding in our memories
entry.summary:
Cravings may feel impulsive, but new research suggests they‚Äôre often rooted in memory. Scientists have found that the brain encodes high-calorie foods in a way that can quietly influence what we eat‚Äîeven when we‚Äôre not hungry. New research reveals that memories of fatty and sugary foods are encoded in the hippocampus, helping explain why some cravings feel impossible to resist.
The next time you remember a chocolate bar in a desk drawer, your brain might not just be recalling it‚Äîit could be actively pushing you to seek it out.
A recent study published in Nature Metabolism suggests that specific neurons in the hippocampus log the sensory and emotional details of calorie-rich food. In mice, these neurons triggered cravings, leading to overeating‚Äîeven when the animals weren‚Äôt hun‚Ä¶

entry.title: Banff is stunning‚Äîand crowded. Here are 7 alternatives
entry.summary:
A mountain climber‚Äîperched on Bugaboo Spire in Bugaboo National Park‚Äîlooks out at the sun with the Purcell Mountain Range in the background. From the aurora-lit skies of Canada‚Äôs newest dark sky park to the tiny railway town near one of Canada‚Äôs tallest waterfalls, these under-the-radar spots offer plenty of room to roam.
You‚Äôve seen the social media posts: the towering and rugged peaks, the glossy, glacial lakes, and the lumbering bears disappearing into thick forests. This is Banff National Park, one of the most beautiful‚Äîand famous‚Äîplaces on Earth.¬†
According to Banff and Lake Louise Tourism, nearly four million people visited Banff in 2024 alone, and¬†overtourism is a growing concern for Parks Canada. So, right now, it‚Äôs an opportune time for travelers¬†to explore alternativ‚Ä¶

entry.title: American Crying
entry.summary: People cry for different reasons and some tend to cry more than others. What makes people cry the most? Tags: crying

entry.title: 7 of the world‚Äôs quirkiest coastal celebrations
entry.summary:
Songkran, or Thailand's Buddhist New Year, is a celebration to cleanse and rejuvenate for the year ahead. On the streets, traditions take on a playful tone, in the form of an almighty water fight. From epic water fights and night-long cave raves to extravagant fruit-laden parades, these kooky events all make the most of the coast.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
There‚Äôs no better way to tap into the soul of a destination than by diving headfirst into a local festival, when communities come alive in the most joyous ways ‚Äî be it dancing, feasting or honouring a time-old tradition. Throw in a coastline, and the magic multiplies: the tang of salt in the air, the lure of the day‚Äôs catch and a backdrop of shifting seascapes all heighten the atmosp‚Ä¶

entry.title: A practical guide to exploring Europe's mighty Danube River
entry.summary:
Danube is a popular river cruising destination in Europe. Saxon puppetry, galleries and gardens: here's how to make the most of a short break in this German city.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Snaking almost 1,800 miles from its source in Germany‚Äôs Black Forest to the Black Sea in Romania, the Danube is best explored slowly. Cruises, the most popular option, provide up-close encounters with the river, allowing you to see plenty in just a week or two. They don‚Äôt have to be obvious, with some cracking off-beat options taking you east and into the wilds of the Lower Danube. For an adventure at your own pace, consider hiking on a network of well-developed, marked trails or cycling the long-distance Danube Cycle Path, which largely shadows the r‚Ä¶

entry.title: The world‚Äôs rarest penguins don‚Äôt avoid heat‚Äîthey embrace it
entry.summary:
Gal√°pagos penguins populate Isabela Island, where they are joined by marine iguanas. Both animals occupy fissures in the coastline‚Äôs volcanic rock and forage in the ocean. These birds have evolved to withstand the equatorial sun and shelter in volcanic rocks along a subtropical coastline. After 50 years, biologist Dee Boersma continues to learn new things about the species.
Roughly 600 miles¬†off the coast of mainland Ecuador, conservation biologist Dee Boersma cruised in an inflatable Zodiac through the blue waters surrounding Bartolom√© Island, a small part of the Pacific Ocean archipelago known as the Gal√°pagos Islands. She was joined by several other scientists, all of whom scanned the shoreline for an elusive black-and-white seabird. Standing about a foot and a half tall, Gal√°pa‚Ä¶

entry.title: How global warming is disrupting life on Earth
entry.summary:
People view artist Luke Jerram's 'Floating Earth' at an urban lake in Wigan, England. The sculpture brought attention to global warming, the worldwide rise in temperature that's causing major climatic changes.  A warmer planet doesn‚Äôt just raise temperatures. From wildfires to floods, here's how the climate is changing.
Since the Industrial Revolution‚Äîan event made possible by the use of fossil fuels in everything from power plants to transportation‚ÄîEarth has gotten hotter.
2024 was the hottest year on record and the first year Earth's temperature surpassed 1.5¬∞C (2.7¬∞F).
The past 10 years have been the 10 hottest years on record, and a reconstruction of Earth's average temperature over the past 485 million years showed that when the planet warms, catastrophic weathe‚Ä¶

entry.title: How Antarctica‚Äôs penguins became nature‚Äôs daredevils
entry.summary:
Hundreds of emperor juveniles survived jumping into the sea from a 50-foot ice shelf last year. The impact may have been minimized by their small size, plentiful feathers on their belly, and strong breast muscles. From diving off cliffs to starving for months, emperor penguins are continuing to surprise scientists with their ability to adapt to one of the world‚Äôs most extreme environments.
‚ÄúOh my god,¬†this thing‚Äôs going to die.‚Äù That was the thought running through the mind of wildlife filmmaker Bertie Gregory when he saw the first juvenile emperor penguin jump off a 50-foot cliff. The bird plummeted downward, splashing into the frigid Southern Ocean. After a few suspenseful seconds, it bobbed to the surface and then swam off toward the horizon. The National Geographic Explorer cou‚Ä¶

entry.title: What ‚Äòtrash heap‚Äô penguins can teach us about survival
entry.summary:
Chinstrap and gentoo penguins, shown here near Danco Island in Antarctica, regularly plunge to depths of over 100 feet on foraging runs. For more than 60 million years, penguins of all kinds‚Äîincluding the opportunistic Magellanic penguin‚Äîhave been driven by an evolutionary urge to reach beyond their boundaries. Today, many are surfacing in the most unlikely places.
When Pablo ‚ÄúPopi‚Äù¬†Borboroglu first visited a remote stretch of shoreline along the eastern coast of Patagonia, in 2008, the National Geographic Explorer was surprised to find penguins making a home there. The Argentine biologist was responding to a call from a nearby rancher who had seen several of the flightless birds on his property. When he arrived, Borboroglu found trash, broken glass, abandoned cars, and burned-out ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 166 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Center‚Äôs nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from March 24 to March 30, 2025. A total of 3,605 panelists responded out of 4,045 who were sampled, [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals.¬†¬†¬† Moira Fagan, Research Associate¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Jacob Poushter, Associate Director, Global Attitudes ResearchSneha Gubbala, Research Analyst Dorene Asare-Marfo, Senior Panel ManagerPeter Bell, Associate Director, Design and ProductionJanakee Chavda, Associate Digital ProducerLaura Clancy, Research AnalystJonathan Evans, Senior ResearcherJanell Fetterolf, Senior ResearcherShannon Greenwood, Digital [‚Ä¶] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. How Americans view NATO and U.S. NATO membership
entry.summary: Most Americans feel positively toward NATO. Democrats remain more likely than Republicans to say the U.S. benefits from membership. The post 3. How Americans view NATO and U.S. NATO membership appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. How Americans view the Russia-Ukraine war
entry.summary: 44% of Americans say the U.S. has a responsibility to aid in Ukraine's defense. But the partisan gap on this issue has grown. The post 2. How Americans view the Russia-Ukraine war appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. How Americans view Russia and Putin
entry.summary: Half of Americans see Russia as an enemy of the U.S., down since last year. Views of Russia and Putin remain largely negative. The post 1. How Americans view Russia and Putin appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Republican Opinion Shifts on Russia-Ukraine War
entry.summary: Republicans are less likely than last year to say Russia is an enemy and to say the U.S. has a responsibility to help Ukraine defend itself. The post Republican Opinion Shifts on Russia-Ukraine War appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Views of trade between China and the U.S.
entry.summary: Americans tend to say U.S.-China trade benefits China more, though they‚Äôre skeptical that increased tariffs on China will be good for themselves or the U.S. The post 3. Views of trade between China and the U.S. appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Views of China‚Äôs role in the world
entry.summary: Most Americans say China‚Äôs global influence is growing stronger. Still, they tend to see the U.S. as the world‚Äôs top economic and military power. The post 2. Views of China‚Äôs role in the world appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. U.S. views of China and Xi
entry.summary: Americans hold largely negative opinions of China and Xi Jinping, but ratings of both have improved slightly since 2024. The post 1. U.S. views of China and Xi appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Negative Views of China Have Softened Slightly Among Americans
entry.summary: Americans see China unfavorably, but the share with this view has dropped for the first time in five years. The post Negative Views of China Have Softened Slightly Among Americans appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: ‚úö Breaking Out of Chart Software Defaults
entry.summary: Defaults are good for quick and disposable charts. However, when the audience extends beyond yourself, it's time to customize around purpose. Tags: default, editing, highlight

entry.title: Record hunger in Haiti amid rising needs
entry.summary: Escalating armed violence, displacement, economic turmoil and disruptions to local food production are fueling hunger in Haiti and leaving millions at risk, the UN World Food Programme (WFP) said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan: No respite for civilians amid unrelenting war and aid access barriers
entry.summary: As Sudan‚Äôs civil war grinds on, millions of civilians remain trapped in a relentless cycle of displacement, hunger and violence, while relief efforts are stifled by insecurity and bureaucratic hurdles.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Libya‚Äôs fragile transition plagued by deepening economic and political divides
entry.summary: Libya‚Äôs prolonged political transition is facing renewed strain, with mounting economic pressures and tensions between rival governments threatening the calm that has held since the 2020 ceasefire.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Universal Declaration of Human Rights among new entries to UNESCO Memory of the World Register
entry.summary: The archives of British naturalist Charles Darwin, whose theory of evolution by natural selection revolutionized understanding of nature and humanity‚Äôs place within it, are among 74 new additions to a UN list of documentary heritage of universal value.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Rise in violence against civilians in South Sudan
entry.summary: The number of civilians in South Sudan harmed by conventional parties to the conflict and other armed groups increased by 51 per cent in 2024, the UN Mission in the country (UNMISS) said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Alongside conflict, an information war is still happening, warns UNRWA chief
entry.summary: Amid reported Israeli strikes across the Gaza Strip into Thursday that killed at least 23 people, the head of the UN agency for Palestinian refugees, UNRWA, issued an urgent call to ‚Äúget international media into Gaza‚Äù to cover the conflict, in addition to those reporters trapped in the enclave.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Asymmetric Monstrosity map projection
entry.summary: Part amusement and part learning exercise, the ‚Äúasymmetric monstrosity‚Äù by Daniel Huffman is‚Ä¶ Tags: Daniel Huffman, projections

entry.title: Squirrel on my shoulder
entry.summary: Meet Sammy Squitten, the baby squirrel suckled by a cat and raised by a human, in this story narrated by David Attenborough - by Aeon Video Watch at Aeon

entry.title: Welcome to the Chaoscene
entry.summary: The climate crisis is here. In order to thrive in these dangerous and precarious times, we must build resilient communities - by Rupert Read Read at Aeon

entry.title: These are the 10 most popular national parks
entry.summary:
Since the U.S. National Park Service (NPS) started keeping records in 1904, its mountain landscapes, seaside wildernesses, and high desert acres have registered more than 16.4 billion visits. Some of the best-known parks experienced record crowds in 2024. Straddling the border between North Carolina and Tennessee, Great Smoky Mountains National Park passed 12 million recreation visits; almost 3.2 million people took in the massive U-shaped valleys and hulking granite peaks carved by ice flows long ago at Montana's Glacier National Park.
Visitors are drawn to the vastness and variety of ‚ÄúAmerica‚Äôs best idea.‚Äù From sea to shining sea (as well as in the wilds of Alaska and Hawaii), the NPS‚Äôs 85 million acres encompass 150,000 miles of rivers and streams and over 21,000 miles of trails.¬† ‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to see the northern lights‚Äîand why they‚Äôre more common now
entry.summary:
The northern lights, or aurora borealis, hang above the fishing village of Reine on Norway's Lofoten archipelago. The best places to see this ethereal display are in "auroral zones" that are close to Earth's poles‚Äîbut sometimes you can see them from even farther north and south.

The aurora borealis and aurora australis have dazzled us in the night sky for centuries. Here‚Äôs what causes them‚Äîand where the best places are to catch a glimpse. No matter how many times you see them, the northern lights, or aurora borealis‚Äîand their Southern Hemisphere equivalent, the aurora australis‚Äîare an ethereal, breathtaking sight. Dancing silently in Earth‚Äôs upper atmosphere, they form iridescent sheets of green and red (or sometimes blue and purple) ‚Ä¶

Running pros and eye experts say these are the best running sunglasses
entry.summary:

As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*¬†
Hang out at a track or scroll through photos of a running event, and you‚Äôll notice that many runners don‚Äôt wear sunglasses. But they should. Eye experts consistently advise wearing sunglasses whenever you‚Äôre outside to decrease the risk of eye damage and diseases.¬†
Quality running sunglasses should be lightweight, so you feel like you‚Äôre not even wearing them. They should fit snugly, so they don‚Äôt bounce as you move. They should also have sweat-res‚Ä¶

entry.title: How dragons lost their wicked menace‚Äîand became our friends
entry.summary:
‚ÄúI desired dragons with a profound desire,‚Äù fantasy writer J.R.R. Tolkien once said about his childhood imagination, captivated as he was¬†with the creatures of myth. That desire shaped his work for the rest of his life, and Tolkien‚Äôs Smaug, the great fire breathing villain of The Hobbit,¬†has loomed large in our cultural imaginations, but he was far from alone in his fascination. ¬†
Cultures around the world told stories about enormous, powerful, serpent-like creatures for centuries. From Mesopotamia to China and ancient Greece, the dragon has slithered alongside humanity, its lore ever-evolving, though many of the tropes are familiar even today: It crouches in caves on piles of gold, reeking of brimstone, waiting for intrepid heroes, or they take to the air, an ominous shadow that pass‚Ä¶

entry.title: What is Good Friday‚Äîand what‚Äôs the meaning behind its name?
entry.summary:
For billions of Christians, Good Friday remains one of the holiest days in the religious calendar. Commemorating the day Jesus died by crucifixion around A.D. 30., Good Friday is a crucial part of the Christian Holy Week, the series of holidays that culminates in Easter, when, according to Christian faith, Jesus returned to life after dying on the cross.¬†
What‚Äôs the context behind Good Friday‚Äîand how do Christians observe it every year?¬†¬†
Good Friday represents Jesus‚Äô execution at the hands of the Romans. So why do Christians call the holiday ‚Äúgood‚Äù?¬†
‚Äú‚ÄòGood‚Äô in this instance means something like ‚Äòholy‚Äô or ‚Äòpious.‚Äô It is ‚Äògood‚Äô because it is ‚Äòholy,‚Äô not because we are supposed to think that crucifixion is a good thing,‚Äù explains¬†Candida Moss, Edward Cadbury Professor of Th‚Ä¶

entry.title: Mary Magdalene probably wasn‚Äôt a prostitute. Was she rich?
entry.summary:
This piece is adapted from the second edition of In The Footsteps of Jesus: A Chronicle of His Life and the Origins of Christianity.
Jesus may have traveled to the town that Matthew refers to as Magadan, which could mean Magdala (in fact, certain Greek manuscripts actually use the word ‚ÄúMagdala‚Äù). Magdala was a major processing center of the Galilean fishing industry. Among others, it was renowned throughout the region for its fish sauce, a popular condiment in Antiquity.
One of Jesus‚Äô followers actually came from Magdala. Her name was Mary, ‚Äúthe Magdalene,‚Äù but the Gospels give us very little information about her background. Unlike other women named ‚ÄúMary‚Äù in the Gospels, Mary Magdalene appears to be unattached, which was unusual. As scholars K. C. Hanson and Douglas Oakman hav‚Ä¶

entry.title: How one divisive herb became an essential part of Thai cooking
entry.summary:
Blue Elephant‚Äôs tom yum goong soup is flavoured with coriander root and garnished with the leaves. This grassy herb is one of the world‚Äôs most divisive, but in Thailand it‚Äôs an integral part of the cuisine.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
It‚Äôs the middle of dinner service at Bo.lan restaurant in Bangkok and our table for two is packed with all the dishes that make up a traditional Thai meal: salad, a laab of minced grey mullet that smells like nutty, toasted rice kernels; curry, a Southern-style chicken-and-prawn version made creamy with cashew nuts; a protein dish ‚Äî stir-fried beef in a sauce thickened with shrimp paste; and much more besides.

entry.title: Security Council urged to support eastern DR Congo peace initiatives
entry.summary: Despite numerous regional and international diplomatic initiatives, the security situation remains critical in the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), the Security Council heard on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza faces deepening crisis as aid stocks dwindle
entry.summary: The United Nations on Wednesday warned that escalating hostilities and access constraints in Gaza are exacerbating an already dire humanitarian crisis, displacing hundreds of thousands and depriving civilians of shelter, food and medicine.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Partnerships, increased climate investment crucial for sustainable transition, says UN deputy chief
entry.summary: Addressing the opening of an international forum in Hanoi on partnerships for green growth, UN Deputy Secretary-General Amina Mohammed on Wednesday emphasized the need for accelerated action to meet global climate and development goals.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Haiti crisis could impact regional and global stability
entry.summary: The situation in Haiti represents ‚Äúone of the most complex and urgent crises in the world with implications for reginal and global stability,‚Äù¬†said¬†Amy Pope, Director General of¬†International Organisation for Migration (IOM),¬†speaking to journalists in New York on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: South Sudan on the brink as peace deal falters, UN warns
entry.summary: South Sudan stands at a dangerous crossroads as rising political tensions threaten to derail a fragile peace deal, amid growing fears of renewed conflict in the world‚Äôs youngest nation, already buckling under a deepening humanitarian crisis.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Humanitarian situation continues to deteriorate in El Fasher, Sudan
entry.summary: Escalating violence and deteriorating humanitarian conditions in and around El Fasher in Sudan continue to be of grave concern, the United Nations said on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Global growth on recessionary path amid trade tensions and uncertainty
entry.summary: The world economy is on a recessionary trajectory as global growth is expected to slow to 2.3 per cent this year due to escalating trade tensions and uncertainty, the UN trade and development body, UNCTAD, said in a new report published on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Countries finalize historic pandemic agreement after three years of negotiations
entry.summary: In the early hours of Wednesday morning in Geneva, countries finalized a draft global agreement aimed at improving how the world prepares for and responds to pandemics, marking a historic step that will be submitted to the World Health Assembly in May for adoption.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Building an artificial scientist
entry.summary: ‚ÄòArtificial scientists‚Äô can use machine-learning algorithms to design experiments that are beyond the intuition of humans - by Aeon Video Watch at Aeon

entry.title: 12 travel-friendly flip-flops (plus two bonus picks)
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*¬†
Flip-flops are the unsung workhorses of footwear. They come in handy when you‚Äôre traveling whether you‚Äôre padding across hot sand in Hawaii, slipping into something comfortable after a long hike, or simply walking around your hotel. That‚Äôs why our bags are never without a pair.¬†
With so many options to choose from, we asked experts, including podiatrists, and tried out a ton of flip-flops ourselves to find the best options for travelers.¬†
‚ÄúA g‚Ä¶

entry.title: Colossal squid caught on camera for first time in natural habitat
entry.summary:
The colossal squid‚Äîone of nature‚Äôs most elusive animals, and handily the world‚Äôs most massive squid species‚Äîwas first identified 100 years ago using remains found in the stomach of a sperm whale. Now, for the very first time, one has been filmed alive in its natural oceanic environment.
On March 9, the U.S.-based Schmidt Ocean Institute‚Äôs research vessel, Falkor (too), was exploring the frigid waters close to the South Sandwich Islands, in the southern Atlantic Ocean, as part of an international quest to discover marine life. That day, they deployed a remotely operated submersible down to a depth of almost 2,000 feet, when the colossal squid suddenly drifted past the submersible‚Äôs cameras.
After making sure to verify the footage with a series of experts both on and off the re‚Ä¶

entry.title: Introducing HELMET: ÁªºÂêàËØÑ‰º∞ÈïøÊñáÊú¨ËØ≠Ë®ÄÊ®°Âûã

üìå ‰∏ÄÂè•ËØùÊëòË¶Å

Êú¨Êñá‰ªãÁªç‰∫Ü HELMET (How to Evaluate Long-Context Models Effectively and Thoroughly)ÔºåËøôÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Êó®Âú®ËØÑ‰º∞ÈïøÊñáÊú¨ËØ≠Ë®ÄÊ®°Âûã (LCLMs) ÁöÑÁªºÂêàËØÑÊµãÂü∫ÂáÜ„ÄÇHELMET Ëß£ÂÜ≥‰∫ÜÁé∞ÊúâËØÑ‰º∞ÊñπÊ≥ïÂú®Â§öÊ†∑ÊÄß„ÄÅÂèØÊéßÊÄßÂíåÂèØÈù†ÊÄßÊñπÈù¢ÁöÑÂ±ÄÈôêÊÄß„ÄÇÂÆÉÂåÖÊã¨ÂêÑÁßç‰ªªÂä°ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊ£ÄÁ¥¢Â¢ûÂº∫ÁîüÊàê„ÄÅÂºïÁî®ÁîüÊàêÂíåÊëòË¶ÅÁîüÊàêÔºåÊèê‰æõÂèØÊéßÁöÑËæìÂÖ•ÈïøÂ∫¶ÂíåÈöæÂ∫¶„ÄÇHELMET ÈááÁî®Âü∫‰∫éÊ®°ÂûãÁöÑËØÑ‰º∞‰∏é‰∫∫Â∑•ËØÑ‰º∞Áõ∏ÁªìÂêàÁöÑÊñπÂºèÔºåÂπ∂ÈÄöËøáÊÉÖÂ¢ÉÂ≠¶‰π†ÊîØÊåÅÂü∫Á°ÄÊ®°Âûã„ÄÇÂÆÉËøòÊèê‰æõ‰∫ÜÂÖ≥‰∫éÂ¶Ç‰Ωï‰ΩøÁî® HELMET ËøõË°åËØÑ‰º∞ÁöÑÂÆûÁî®ÊåáÂçó„ÄÇÂÆûÈ™åÁªìÊûúË°®ÊòéÔºå‰∏çÂêå‰ªªÂä°‰πãÈó¥ÁöÑÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÊÄßËæÉ‰ΩéÔºåÂπ∂‰∏îÂú®Â§çÊùÇ‰ªªÂä°ÂíåÈïøÊñáÊú¨‰∏ä‰∏ãÊñá‰∏≠ÊÄßËÉΩ‰∏ãÈôçÔºåÁ™ÅÂá∫‰∫ÜÂ§öÊ†∑ÂåñËØÑ‰º∞ÁöÑÈáçË¶ÅÊÄß„ÄÇHELMET ‰∏∫ LCLMs ÁöÑÊú™Êù•ÂèëÂ±ïÊèê‰æõ‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™Êúâ‰ª∑ÂÄºÁöÑÂ∑•ÂÖ∑„ÄÇ üí° ‰∏ªË¶ÅËßÇÁÇπ

entry.title: 10 unforgettable ways to explore Minnesota
entry.summary:
Welcome to the Land of 10,000 Lakes‚ÄîMinnesota! The North Star State offers locals and visitors alike pristine national and state parks, a culture of welcoming communities, and a rich Scandinavian history‚Äîbut that‚Äôs only a small portion of what awaits you on this Midwest adventure. If narrowing down your options sounds daunting, we recommend you start with this list of not-to-be-missed experiences in Minnesota.¬†
The¬†Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness (BWCAW) is a million pristine acres of glacially-carved lakes and boreal forest along 150 miles of the Minnesota-Canada border‚Äîthe place to go for a remote backcountry experience. Its western edge segues directly into¬†Voyageurs National Park‚Äôs similarly stunning 218,00 acres. Celebrating its 50th anniversary this year, the park is nea‚Ä¶

entry.title: Everything to know about Minnesota, the land of 10,000 lakes
entry.summary:
Travelers planning a trip in the United States, specifically the Midwest, should add¬†¬†Minnesota to their vacation plans. The Star of the North state has a quiet charm, and its reputation extends beyond its subzero temps and long winters. Visitors can choose a variety of ways to uncover the magic of Minnesota through its epic landscapes and truly unique experiences.¬†
Immerse yourself in the natural beauty of Voyageurs National Park, discover the history found along the stunning North Shore of Lake Superior, try a fried candy bar on a stick at the Minnesota State Fair (the Great Minnesota Get-Together), or try the famed Juicy Lucy or an award-winning meal at Hmong restaurant in the Twin Cities. There‚Äôs something for every type of traveler in the Land of 10,000 Lakes.
Spring:¬†When‚Ä¶

entry.title: The best hotels in Minnesota for every type of traveler
entry.summary:
Ribboned by rivers and dotted by more than 10,000 lakes, Minnesota‚Äôs top getaways never stray far from storied waters. The Mississippi River winds through both St. Paul and Minneapolis where urban stays highlight art and architecture in a former convent and coax guests to a rooftop sauna and spa pool overlooking the reflective skyline.¬†Follow the Great River Road to the bluffs of southeastern Minnesota, head ‚ÄúUp North‚Äù to the heart of Lake Country, or hug Lake Superior‚Äôs rugged coast for cozy shoreline escapes.
Best for:¬†¬†Foodies¬†
Gourmands should check into this seven-room boutique hotel‚Äîcreated by Alex and Margo Roberts‚Äîhungry. Heady aromas coax visitors inside with spiced almonds, lemon ricotta cookies, and sourdough bread from Caf√© Alma; roasted duck and Meyer lemon orzo fr‚Ä¶

entry.title: Step back in time to 1775 at this historic inn
entry.summary:
It all started with a bang. Well, more precisely, it was a shot‚Äîthe ‚Äúshot heard round the world‚Äù that began the Revolutionary War.
On the night of April 18, 1775‚Äîinto the early hours of the 19th‚ÄîPaul Revere rode directly past the site where I stand, looking up at the Minuteman Statue illuminated by spotlights at twilight. Local historian and leader of the Footsteps of the Revolution tour Fred Silverstein knows the details so well that you would swear that he was actually there himself. ‚ÄúPeople are surprised to learn that Revere was not ‚Äúon the opposite shore‚Äù to wait for a signal according to Longfellow,‚Äù Silverstein explains. ‚ÄúHe wasn‚Äôt even the first rider summoned to warn Hancock and Adams in Lexington. Revere did arrive in Lexington first, having taken a shorter route with a faste‚Ä¶

entry.title: Can you trust your gut? What science reveals about intuition
entry.summary:
There are many times in life when we have to make decisions without having all of the information‚Äîwhether that‚Äôs a split-second decision during a crisis or a major life decision such as accepting a new job. In these situations, we often find ourselves relying on our intuition, in the hope that our unconscious knowledge can help us choose the right path.¬†
Intuition is the¬†ability to attain knowledge or make decisions without evident rational thought and inference. For a long time, intuition has been thought of as something almost mystical‚Äîsomething that might be good or might be bad, but that is nonetheless beyond our ability to define let alone quantify how much it really helps us.¬†
(Does trusting your doctor's gut feeling lead to better care?)
Even though intuition has been‚Ä¶

entry.title: Will we still see fireflies this summer?
entry.summary:
Rapha√´l De Cock was 9 years old the day he caught his first firefly, the glowing insect he‚Äôd read about with great interest in his grandfather‚Äôs nature books. While exploring the Belgian countryside, he lifted a stone and found a treasure: the larvae of a common glow-worm, a firefly species widespread in Europe, Africa, and Asia.¬†
While running back to his grandparents‚Äô house with the critter, he tripped and lost it in the grass. The insect was gone. But days later, while taking a walk on a humid summer night, De Cock and his grandmother returned to the spot where he lost the firefly and were greeted by a breathtaking sight: Hundreds of little lights were re-creating a starry sky on earth.¬†
Yet if De Cock returns to this childhood spot in the countryside, something is missing‚Ä¶

entry.title: World News in Brief: Relief supplies for Myanmar, invest in Haiti, child migrant deaths in Italy
entry.summary: A plane carrying some 40 metric tonnes of lifesaving aid arrived in Myanmar from Dubai on Tuesday to support survivors of the devastating earthquake last month.

entry.summary: Young people from across the globe are meeting at UN Headquarters this week to share their recommendations to transform the world into a fairer, greener and more sustainable place.

entry.summary: An Israeli strike on a hospital in southern Gaza on Tuesday has further jeopardized already limited access to lifesaving medical care in the war-torn enclave.

entry.title: UN forum tackles slavery reparations for Africa, people of African descent
entry.summary: The calls for reparatory justice can no longer be ignored, speakers at the fourth session of the United Nations Permanent Forum on African Descent in New York said on Tuesday.

entry.title: Israeli strikes in Lebanon continue to kill civilians, UN rights office warns
entry.summary: Israeli military operations in Lebanon have continued to claim civilian lives and destroy vital infrastructure, the UN human rights office warned on Tuesday, raising alarm over mounting violations since a ceasefire agreement took effect last November.

entry.title: America has a 740-mile river adventure finally being revealed
entry.summary:
The rain came down¬†in sheets, roiling the surface of Fourth Lake, an oblong crescent in the heart of New York‚Äôs Adirondack Mountains and the largest of eight lakes in the Fulton chain. I laid my paddle on my knees and looked around. Our small flotilla of canoes and kayaks, containing a dozen or so paddlers, was spread out over a half mile, though the downpour obscured many of my companions. We were hustling toward the closest takeout, a mile away on Fifth Lake.
Only a few hours earlier, I had shoved off from the tiny hamlet of Old Forge, in upstate New York, pushing east with a group of Native American paddlers along a portion of an ancient route that runs for 740 miles to Maine. The Northern Forest Canoe Trail (NFCT) is made up of a network of more than 80 lakes, ponds, rivers, and s‚Ä¶

entry.title: This one muscle could be the key to fixing your back pain
entry.summary:
Lower back pain can stab, throb, or ache without warning. But what if the problem wasn‚Äôt actually coming from your back?
It‚Äôs easy to blame posture or a pulled muscle. But an overlooked culprit may be buried deeper: your hip flexors‚Äîspecifically, the psoas (pronounced so-EZZ).
This ribbon-like muscle curls from the top of your femur, over the front of the pelvis, and up to your lumbar spine and lower ribs. It‚Äôs part of the iliopsoas complex, says Richard Lau, a clinical assistant professor in the Department of Rehabilitation Medicine at NYU Grossman School of Medicine‚Äîthe muscle group often cited when athletes suffer ‚Äúhip flexor strains.‚Äù
After age 30, everyone loses 4 to 6 percent of their psoas muscle mass every decade, and it decreases even more rapidly for men after 60. ‚Ä¶

entry.title: The ancient empire that civilization forgot
entry.summary:
At its height,¬†the ancient city of Hattu≈üa, capital of the Hittite civilization, must have been awe-inspiring. Built into a steep hillside in what is today central T√ºrkiye, the city was ringed by tall brick walls. It was home to as many as 7,000 people, vast temple complexes, and an imposing stone rampart visible from miles away. Today the hillside is home to a mystery.
No pillars or high walls mark the ruins of the palace and temples that once stood‚Äîjust stone foundations half-covered by dry grass. Some of the city‚Äôs gates still stand, guarded by statues of lions, sphinxes, and an axe-wielding god. But much is gone. The mud-brick walls have crumbled over the centuries; floods and snowmelt have eroded the original hillside, sending buildings full of clay tablets cascading down the slo‚Ä¶

entry.summary: Today a bitter dispute about the nature of biology is underway. A simple bag of beans may be what tips the balance - by Zachary B Hancock Read at Aeon

entry.title: How this German city is capitalizing on its spirit of renewal
entry.summary:
The Frauenkirche is a Lutheran church that dates back to the 18th century. Relics of war still linger in this German city but the Saxon capital is defined by a defiant spirit of renewal, with a thriving cultural scene and cutting-edge nightlife.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
‚ÄúSafe travels. And don‚Äôt touch the bomb!‚Äù It‚Äôs a disorientating message to hear crackling through my phone as my Deutsche Bahn train glides through the outer suburbs of Dresden on a chilly, darkening evening. I feel like Billy Pilgrim, the time-travelling protagonist of Kurt Vonnegut‚Äôs war novel Slaughterhouse-Five, barrelling headlong into the 1945 firebombing that remains intertwined with the fate of this German city.
But the caller, art historian Dr Rudolf Fisch‚Ä¶

entry.title: Behind the FOI Desk: Using Freedom of Information Laws to Fuel Accountability Stories in Africa
entry.summary: Newsrooms across Africa have established formal, right-to-information help desks that leverage government document requests for public accountability and watchdog reporting.

entry.title: The forgotten secret Nazi bases in the Arctic
entry.summary:
The Arctic archipelago of Svalbard is one of the most remote places on earth‚Äîmore than 500 miles north of Europe, and about as far from the North Pole, it was entirely uninhabited by humans until the late 19th century, aside for a few early attempts by whalers to overwinter that mostly ended in disaster. The original name for this archipelago was ‚ÄúSpitsbergen,‚Äù translated from Dutch it means simply ‚Äúpointy mountains,‚Äù and from the distance of a ship at sea, that‚Äôs all one sees here: jagged, snow-capped mountains spaced apart by glaciers that push their way between them towards the sea.¬†¬†
Only on land do you see there‚Äôs more: flocks of seabirds, including fulmars, skuas, and auks, and in summer the bright splotches of orange and purple from the lichen that grows here. Mines were first ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Is this really a dire wolf?
entry.summary:
Colossal Biosciences claims to have resurrected dire wolves by giving modern gray wolves DNA extracted from dire wolf fossils. But whether the wolves truly count as a de-extinction is still up for debate.  Genetics and behavior complicate efforts to bring back extinct species.
For over 200,000 years, dire wolves roamed across North America‚Äîfrom southern Alberta, Canada to Florida, and even down into Chile. The ancient animals were megafauna hunters, ultimately disappearing with the last giant ground sloths and mastodons about 13,000 years ago. Yet this week, Time proclaimed their second coming with a white wolf on its cover.
The private company Colossal Biosciences claims to have resurrected dire wolves through genetic editing. The resulting trio, named Romu‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to plan the perfect trip to Williamsburg, Virginia
entry.summary:
A fife and drum band perform in Virginia‚Äôs reconstructed colonial captial of Williamsburg, where American Revolution history is brought to life in the 21st century. This hub of American colonial history features cobblestone streets, botanical gardens, theme parks‚Äîand a 300-acre living history museum. Here‚Äôs our guide to where to stay, what to eat, and what to do.
Established in 1699 as the capital of the Virginia colony, Williamsburg is an internationally recognized hub of American colonial history. Its historic center features hundreds of 18th-century buildings along cobblestone streets, presenting a charming juxtaposition of past and present as one of the country‚Äôs earliest planned cities.
Williamsburg forms an integral part of Virginia‚Äôs Historic Triangle, alongside Jamesto‚Ä¶

entry.title: Don‚Äôt leave Tokyo without these must-do experiences
entry.summary: Forget the notion that Tokyo is nothing but a concrete sprawl, neon and crowds‚Äîthat tells only a small part of the city‚Äôs story. From centuries-old festivals and calming gardens to cutting-edge galleries and culture classes, these seven experiences will help you discover the many other sides of Japan‚Äôs capital.¬† ¬†Fireworks light up the sky over the Sumida River during the Sumida River Fireworks Festival in Tokyo. Every year, around one million people attend Tokyo‚Äôs Sumida River Fireworks Festival, the largest and most popular fireworks festival in Japan. With festivals taking place throughout the year in Tokyo, you have a good chance that your trip will coincide with a celebration of some kind. If you feel like braving the summer heat and humidity, head to Koenji on the fina‚Ä¶

entry.title: Everything you need to know for the perfect Tokyo trip
entry.summary:
In Tokyo‚Äôs Harajuku district, the Meiji-jingu, also known as Meiji Shrine, is dedicated to Emperor Meiji and Empress Shoken. From transport tips to the best seasons for a visit, here‚Äôs the lowdown on the best way to explore Japan's capital city.
One of the world‚Äôs most populous cities, Tokyo brings together many of the elements that make Japan so popular with travelers. Visit youthful Shibuya and upscale Ginza to experience the modern side of Tokyo, then seek out moments of tradition at Meiji Jingu shrine, Senso-ji temple and Rikugi-en garden. Hike Mt. Takao for a taste of Japan‚Äôs great outdoors. Depending on when you come, you could time your visit for cherry blossom season or any number of traditional festivals. And don‚Äôt forget the food. From sublime sushi to comforting ra‚Ä¶

entry.title: Milan has a hidden aperitivo scene. Here‚Äôs where the locals go.
entry.summary:
A good spritz is a moment; a great one is a memory. Aperitivo stems from the Latin aperire, which means "to open." And in Milan, you can open up to new experiences, flavors, and unexpected friendships. This pre-dinner ritual is less about sips and bites than taking your time and witnessing the city at its best.
If you want to find the best spots, ask a bartender. These unsung alchemists‚Äîtwisting, muddling, and doling out liquid magic‚Äîknow where Milan‚Äôs best-kept secrets lie. Let them be your divining rod to the city‚Äôs best watering holes; a world where every cocktail is a manifesto. Only four customers at a time can fit into BackDoor 43. The bar serves takeaway cocktails, like the Boulevardier. On the lively banks of the Naviglio Grande canal, BackDoor 43 stakes its cla‚Ä¶

entry.title: 8 family-friendly things to do in Tokyo
entry.summary:
Girls eat cotton candy on Takeshita Street in Tokyo's Harajuku area. From a life-size helicopter to a micro-pig caf√©, your kids won‚Äôt want to miss these cool attractions on your next trip to Tokyo.
You can thank anime, manga, and Mario Kart for Japan‚Äôs consistent popularity with kids. If your kids are chasing Pok√©mon or digging into their favorite flavor of Pocky, a trip to Tokyo, Japan‚Äôs largest city, won‚Äôt disappoint. Its distinctive architecture, fast (fun) food, and collectible culture are perfect for kids. And for families hoping to introduce their kids to Japanese history, nature, and culture, Tokyo feels like a one-stop-shop. Lure the kids in with their favorite shows and games, then surprise and delight them with a city with opportunities for intercultural connection around‚Ä¶

entry.summary: The 12th hole at Augusta National Golf Club, where the Masters is held,‚Ä¶ Tags: golf, Reuters

entry.title: How to plan the perfect trip to this hidden corner of Sardinia
entry.summary:
Sheltering cliffs create ideal swimming conditions at Cala Spinosa beach in Capo Testa. Sardinia‚Äôs Costa Smeralda is this region‚Äôs calling card, but travel beyond and you‚Äôll discover low-key beaches, distinctive food and mysterious Neolithic sites.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
‚ÄòSardinia is out of time and history‚Äô, D H Lawrence wrote in his 1921 travel book Sea and Sardinia. ‚ÄòThis land resembles no other place.‚Äô More than a century later, his words still ring true in Gallura, which spreads north of the city of Olbia in the Italian island‚Äôs mountainous north east. Although the region is best known for the blue water and white sands of its high-end Costa Smeralda or ‚ÄòEmerald Coast‚Äô, elsewhere it has a raw beauty. Wild boars roam its foreste‚Ä¶

entry.title: Hate cilantro or anchovies? Evolutionary science could explain why.
entry.summary:
Black licorice, oysters, and anchovies are the most hated foods in the U.S., according to an analysis of Instacart purchases and online surveys collected by the grocery delivery service. But many consider these foods a delicacy‚Äîso why are certain foods so divisive?
Our early human ancestors may have relied on their sense of taste to identify nutritious new foods and avoid toxins. As a result, scientists think we tend to dislike bitter foods because plant poisons¬†taste bitter, and we tend to like sweet foods because our brains identify sweetness as glucose, a great source of energy.
But today, with our food designed, engineered, and processed to have an array of flavors, these defense mechanisms aren‚Äôt as helpful. With ultra processed foods making up over half of U.S. adults‚Äô ener‚Ä¶

entry.title: Sudan: 15 million children require humanitarian assistance after two years of war
entry.summary: The number of children in need of humanitarian assistance in Sudan has doubled as the war between rival militaries enters a third year on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Millions displaced, health system in ruins as Sudan war fuels famine
entry.summary: More than 12.4 million people have been forced from their homes across Sudan ‚Äì including over 3.3 million refugees who have fled to neighbouring countries ‚Äì as two years of civil war fuel famine, disease outbreaks and the collapse of the health system.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Gaza aid crisis worsens, South Sudan clashes, Ecuador oil spill update
entry.summary: The humanitarian situation in Gaza is now likely the worst it has been in the 18 months since the outbreak of hostilities, the UN relief coordination office, OCHA, reported on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN forum on People of African Descent examines reparations and AI challenge
entry.summary: The fourth session of the UN Permanent Forum on People of African Descent opened on Monday at United Nations Headquarters in New York.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan war: ‚ÄòDarkest chapters‚Äô ahead as Darfur massacre claims over 100 lives
entry.summary: As Sudan‚Äôs devastating war enters its third year, UN rights investigators are warning that its ‚Äúdarkest chapters‚Äù may still lie ahead, following the massacre of more than 100 people at displacement camps in Darfur over the weekend.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Thousands of Gaza patients waiting for urgent medical evacuation
entry.summary: The Israeli bombardment of Al-Ahli, a Gaza City hospital, has put even more pressure on the remaining health facilities in the occupied Palestinian territory, where the delivery of aid and movement of humanitarian workers is highly restricted by the Israeli authorities.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN denounces deadly Palm Sunday attack in Ukraine
entry.summary: The United Nations has condemned the Russian attack on the city of Sumy, Ukraine, on Sunday which reportedly killed at least 34 people, including two children, and injured more than 100 others.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Israeli attack puts last functioning hospital in Gaza City out of service
entry.summary: The last functioning hospital in Gaza City has been put out of action by an Israeli strike at the weekend, while a child patient with reported head trauma died while being evacuated, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) said on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: New Free Tools to Track Corporate Misconduct Around the World
entry.summary: The new Violation Tracker Global (VT Global) portal offers unique and valuable datasets on corporate misconduct across 57 countries and territories outside of the US and UK.

entry.title: Explore the French city that's embraced North African cuisine
entry.summary:
From Marseille's Basilica of Notre Dame de la Garde, visitors can catch a view of the sea and the city below. One of Europe‚Äôs most multicultural cities, Marseille is home to a large North African population whose traditional dishes such as Brik pastry ‚Äî sometimes given a modern twist ‚Äî have become a key part of the local culinary culture.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
On the plate is what looks like a fist-sized, deep-fried wonton, perched on a dollop of deep red paste and paired with a wedge of lime.
I crack open the golden pastry shell to reveal a just-cooked egg on a bed of spiced potatoes studded with capers and strewn with luscious flakes of confit tuna.
Here at Marseille‚Äôs Les Rigoles restaurant, chef Johann Barichasse draws‚Ä¶

entry.title: Taraji P. Henson on Southern food, travel and Moscato wine
entry.summary:
Taraji talks all things food, travel and Seven Daughters Moscato. The actor discusses the dishes and experiences that have shaped her life, including her grandmother‚Äôs barbecue chicken and discovering incredible vegan sushi in Bali.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Anytime I see a watermelon with black seeds, it takes me straight back to my grandparents‚Äô backyard in the South. I‚Äôd bust it open as a kid. Its juice would run down my elbows and I‚Äôd have to run away from the bees. One [set of] grandparents had a livestock farm with chickens, cows and pigs, and the other had a produce garden. They lived off the fat of the land. This was in North Carolina and Maryland.
My grandmother makes a barbecue chicken that‚Äôs specific to North and South C‚Ä¶

entry.title: Resilience in the face of thirst: Trucking water in war-ravaged Gaza
entry.summary: In Gaza, where lack of access to water is an existential threat, Ibrahim Alloush stands out as an unsung hero, providing a lifeline to the thirsty people of the Strip.

entry.title: How is the Sudanese civil war destabilising neighbouring countries?
entry.summary: Since April 2023, Sudan, the third-largest country in Africa, has been embroiled in war, as a brutal battle between government forces and a powerful paramilitary group has exacerbated the nation‚Äôs existing crises, including political instability and economic hardship.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: The ‚Äòchinamperos‚Äô have provided Mexico City with food for generations. Do they have a future?
entry.summary: Xochimilco, nestled in the heart of Mexico City, is home to the ‚Äòchinamperos,‚Äô farmers who have used indigenous techniques to grow food for centuries. Today, their way of life is under threat from environmental degradation, urban expansion and climate change.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: 7 must-try adventures on mainland Greece
entry.summary:
The submerged lost city of Pavlopetri lies off the Peloponnese coast. Plot an active break, whether you want to climb up a mountain rife with myths or swim down to a lost city.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
One of the best ways to explore mainland Greece is under your own steam, through the myriad activities on offer here. There are opportunities to don a mask and flippers and snorkel over an ancient submerged city; to climb Mount Olympus, the fabled home of Zeus, king of the gods; to leap into a boat and whitewater-raft down a 7.5-mile-long gorge; and to ski through the quiet backcountry of its Peloponnese mountain range.
Created during a 1960s hydroelectric project to dam four rivers, Greece‚Äôs biggest artificial lake is a fjord-lik‚Ä¶

entry.title: Going to Japan? Here's how to collect station stamps
entry.summary: Japanese station stamps, or eki stamps, can be collecting in most train stations and many tourist attractions in Japan. Japanese eki stamps (station stamps) are a charming feature of Japanese railway culture. Beloved by visitors and oshi-tetsu (train-stamp nerds) alike, collecting them as you make your way around Japan is easy and free, and results in a unique and lasting record of your journey. Here‚Äôs everything you need to know about creating your own eki stamp collection. This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). Now ubiquitous in many of Japan‚Äôs 9,000 stations, the first eki stamp appeared in 1931 at Fukui station near the Sea of Japan coast, where stationmaster Kanichi Tominaga hit upon the idea of a commemorative stamp after a casual conve‚Ä¶
